name: INGRSS
title: International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System
notes:
**Note 1:** **Collect for all years at this time** This SSDI is effective for diagnosis years xxxx    
* For cases diagnosed xxxx-xxxx, leave this SSDI blank

**Note 2:** If more than one Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System is provided, code the stage documented prior to treatment. 
* If no stage is provided before treatment, or it’s unknown if that stage is prior to treatment, then code the available stage

**Note 3:** Image-Defined Risk Factors in Neuroblastic Tumors: Staging requires assessment of whether or not patients have none, or one or more of the image-defined risk factors (IDRF). These IDRF’s are based on imaging prior to any surgical resection or other treatment. 
* Neck
   - Tumor encasing carotid and/or vertebral artery and/or internal jugular vein
   - Tumor extending to base of skull
   - Tumor compressing the trachea
* Cervico-thoracic junction
   - Tumor encasing brachial plexus roots
   - Tumor encasing subclavian vessels and/or vertebral and/or carotid artery
   - Tumor compressing the trachea
* Thorax
   -  Tumor encasing the aorta and/or major branches
   - Tumor compressing the trachea and/or principal bronchi
   - Lower mediastinal tumor, infiltrating the costovertebral junction between T9 and T12
* Abdomen Pelvis 
   - Tumor infiltrating the porta hepatis and/or the hepatoduodenal ligament
   - Tumor encasing branches of the superior mesenteric artery at the mesenteric root
   - Tumor encasing the origin of the coeliac axis, and/or of the superior mesenteric artery
   - Tumor invading one or both renal pedicles
   - Tumor encasing the aorta and/or vena cava
* Intraspinal tumor extension whatever the location provided that
   - More than one third of the spinal canal in the axial plane is invaded and/or the perimedullary eptomeningeal spaces are not visible and/or the spinal cord signal is abnormal 
* Infiltration of adjacent organs/structures
   - Pericardium, diaphragm, kidney, liver, duodeno-pancreatic block, and mesentery 


**Note 4:** Ascites and/or a pleural effusion, even with malignant cells, do not constitute metastatic disease unless they are remote from the body compartment of the primary tumor.
footnotes:
(1) American Society of Clinical Oncology © 2009, The International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) Classification System: AN INRG Task Force Report; published by American Society of Clinical Oncology, 2009

(2) Aitken JF, Youlden D, O’Neill L, Gupta S, Frazier AL, eds. Childhood cancer staging for population registries according to the Toronto Childhood Cancer Stage Guidelines – Version 2. Cancer Council Queensland and Cancer Australia: Brisbane, Australia; 2021.
rows:
Stage L1
* Localized tumor that does not involve any vital structures
* Tumor confined within one body compartment (i.e., neck, chest, abdomen, or pelvis)
* No evidence of image-defined risk factors (IDRF’s)
* Intraspinal tumor extension that does not fulfil the criteria for an IDRF is consistent with stage (L1) (See Note 5gi)

  WITH or WITHOUT regional lymph node involvement

Physician documents Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System as L1

Stage L2 
* Locoregional tumor with evidence of image-defined risk factors (IDRF’s)
* Tumor ipsilaterally contiguous within body compartments (i.e., a left sided abdominal tumor with left-sided lung, bone or pleura involvement)
   - Non-contiguous disease would be coded as M (e.g. left sided abdominal tumor with right-sided lung, bone or pleura)

   WITH or WITHOUT regional lymph node involvement

Physician documents Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System as L2

Stage M
* Distant metastatic disease (see MS for patients less than 18 months old)
* Noncontiguous disease 
* Distant lymph node involvement

Physician documents Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System as M

Stage MS
* For patients less than 18 months only (547 days)
   - Bone marrow
   - Skin
   - Liver

Physician documents Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System as MS
